awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Scaffolding Pre-service, Early Childhood Teachers to Debug Block-based Programming
awd_abstract_narration:
Engaging early grades students with STEM content in an inquiry-oriented manner is challenging. One way in which this can be done is by having students participate with robots in dramatic play and other student-centered approaches to early childhood education. Programming, and, by consequence, debugging, is critical to the ability to control robot movements. It also contributes to the development of problem-solving skills. It is unreasonable to expect early grades students to gain these skills without being helped by a teacher who has the ability and self-efficacy to engage in debugging. In this three year, collaborative research project, this Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE) Exploration and Design project will prototype and research the effectiveness of strategies to help pre-service, early childhood education teachers learn to debug block-based programming. In so doing, the project has the potential to invite members of a population that is overwhelmingly female (early childhood education pre-service teachers) to participate in computer science, a field in which women are drastically under-represented. It also has the potential to positively influence the teaching of computer science in the early grades among students who are from low-resourced settings or from ethnic minority backgrounds - a very important goal for both social justice and ensuring the widest possible talent pool for the computer science workforce of the future. This aligns with the goals of NSF's IUSE program in that it seeks to enhance STEM education processes and outcomes among pre-service, early childhood teachers, who often suffer from weak STEM education preparation.

The specific project aims are (a) to determine the nature of the motivational and cognitive challenges that impede successful and efficient debugging among pre-service early childhood teachers, and (b) match scaffolding techniques with specific learner characteristics to promote successful and efficient debugging among pre-service early childhood teachers. To address these aims, the project team will engage in 5 studies - (1) an exploratory study of cognitive and motivational challenges that impede successful and efficient debugging among pre-service early childhood teachers, (2) meta-synthesis of exploratory studies (including pilot studies prior to this project) and clusters of participants according to challenges, (3) data mining of a scaffolding meta-analysis dataset and prototyping scaffolding strategies, and (4-5) implementation studies of scaffolding prototypes. Furthermore, the project team will disseminate results to (a) university educators through workshops and webinars, and (b) STEM education researchers through publication of peer-reviewed journal articles.  This important work is supported with funding from the IUSE program and the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Preservice early childhood and elementary teachers who used scaffolding engaged in (a) tinkering as part of a process of abductive reasoning (Kim et al., 2021), (b) analogical reasoning by leveraging multimodal objects (Kim et al., 2023), and (c) collaborative debugging (Kim et al., 2022). We redesigned our scaffolding to support their learning of debugging through abductive reasoning during playful exploration and tinkering, and to guide them to discover a rule that may explain what they were seeing as results of their tinkering (Kim & Belland, 2021). The strongest predictors of debugging quality were debugging process quality, performance-approach goal orientation, and performance avoid goal orientation, which provided a warrant for the use of sound scaffolding strategies (Belland et al., 2021). We found the strongest classifiers of the quality of robotics-enhanced lesson plans to be sentiment analysis scores and word counts (Belland, Kim, et al., 2022). By clustering an expanded meta-analysis dataset, we found that within college- and graduate-level technology and engineering education, scaffolding is most effective when (a) designed to enhance higher order thinking skills, and (b) customized based on performance or not customized (Belland, Lee, et al., 2022). Our participants’ views of coding improved after spending only several hours learning to use coding in early childhood teaching (Belland et al., 2023). In follow-up research integrating coding in mathematics teaching, our participants learned coding and computational thinking as tools to teach conceptual and procedural mathematics (Gleasman & Kim, 2020a, 2020b).  

Broader Impacts

The grant supported 7 PhD students, and 1 undergraduate student, including 5 women and one other member of an underrepresented group, and the writing of three completed dissertations and one master’s thesis.

Early childhood and elementary preservice teachers are almost exclusively women, and this project invited members of that population to computer science. This benefits society in two ways: (a) it exposes women to CS and allows them to choose to engage further, and (b) it provides positive women coder role models for girls in early childhood and elementary education settings.

We worked with 224 preservice early childhood and elementary teachers at 2 universities to learn to debug block-based coding to teach with robots. At one university, preservice teachers taught with robots in field experience in minority serving preschools. 

Publications

This research resulted in 8 peer-reviewed journal articles (Belland et al., 2021; Belland, Kim, et al., 2022; Belland, Lee, et al., 2022; Belland et al., 2023; Gleasman & Kim, 2020a; Kim et al., 2021; Kim, Vasconcelos, et al., 2022; Kim et al., 2023), and 5 peer-reviewed conference proceedings (Gleasman & Kim, 2020b; Kim, Dinç, et al., 2022; Kim et al., 2020; Kim & Belland, 2021; Zhang & Belland, 2023).


Last Modified: 11/11/2023
Modified by: Chanmin Kim
